paper_metadata.title: Balance of potassium in two long-term field experiments with different fertilization treatments
paper_metadata.research_focus: Balance of potassium (K) in long-term stationary field experiments with different fertilization treatments at two sites with different soil and climatic conditions.
paper_metadata.soil_k_relevance: The study is entirely focused on soil potassium biogeochemistry, including K balance, different K pools (exchangeable and non-exchangeable), K recovery rates, and the impact of various fertilization treatments on soil K dynamics over a 21-year period.

research_context.study_objectives: To determine the potassium balance and related changes in soils at different fertilization treatments in long-term field experiments.
research_context.soil_k_research_role: Soil K is the central focus, with investigations into its balance, different forms (bioavailable, exchangeable, non-exchangeable), and how these are affected by long-term fertilization practices and soil/climatic conditions.
research_context.geographic_setting: Two sites in the Czech Republic: Hněvčeves (50°18'46''N, 15°43'3''E) and Humpolec (49°33'16''N, 15°21'2''E).
research_context.environmental_conditions: Hněvčeves: Altitude 265 m a.s.l., Mean annual temperature 8.2 °C, Mean annual precipitation 573 mm. Humpolec: Altitude 525 m a.s.l., Mean annual temperature 7.0 °C, Mean annual precipitation 665 mm.
research_context.agricultural_context: Intensive farming systems typical for the Czech Republic, involving a rotation of potatoes, winter wheat, and spring barley. All three crops were grown each year.
research_context.study_design: Long-term stationary field experiments (21 years, 1996-2017) with 6 different fertilization treatments. Soil samples taken from 0-30 cm depth, four replications, specifically from plots with spring barley for the evaluated data.
research_context.temporal_scope: 21 years (1996-2017), with soil samples analyzed from the beginning (1996) and end (2017) of the experiment.
research_context.spatial_scope: Two distinct experimental sites, each with multiple plots for the 6 fertilization treatments.

pool_characterizations.measurement_conditions: 0-30 cm depth, air-dried soil samples (≤ 2 mm)

treatment_effects.description: Statistically significant differences among individual variants, in compliance with K fertilization intensity. Hněvčeves average was 31% higher than Humpolec. Ranked 'satisfactory pool' or 'good pool' for loamy soils in CR.

pool_characterizations.measurement_conditions: 0-30 cm depth, air-dried soil samples (≤ 2 mm)

treatment_effects.description: Manure application resulted in significant increase. Lowest contents at variants without K fertilization. Hněvčeves content was 34.6% higher than Humpolec.

pool_characterizations.pool_type: K saturation in Cation Exchange Capacity (CEC)

treatment_effects.description: Almost no difference between sites. Content > 3.50% CEC considered satisfactory for these soils.

pool_characterizations.measurement_conditions: 0-30 cm depth, air-dried soil samples (≤ 2 mm)

treatment_effects.description: Significantly lower K content compared to Mehlich 3 and NH4OAc methods. Ratio Hněvčeves/Humpolec was opposite to other methods, possibly due to different clay particle character.

pool_characterizations.measurement_conditions: 0-30 cm depth, finely ground soil samples

treatment_effects.description: Both sites significantly differ due to soil-forming materials. Humpolec (Cambisol on paragneiss) has much higher Kne than Hněvčeves (Luvisol on loess). Fertilization for 21 years did not significantly impact Kne at Humpolec. At Hněvčeves, a significant tendency to decrease Kne was observed in variants without K fertilization.

pool_characterizations.pool_type: Total K extracted by boiling HNO3
pool_characterizations.measurement_conditions: 0-30 cm depth, finely ground soil samples

treatment_effects.description: Represents the total K extracted by this strong acid method, used as a reference for comparing other extraction methods.

process_rates.process: Potassium recovery rate from farmyard manure by crops
process_rates.measurement_approach: Calculated from K input and crop uptake

process_rates.process: Potassium recovery rate from mineral fertilizers by crops
process_rates.measurement_approach: Calculated from K input and crop uptake

assumptions: Outputs determined by yields and K content in plants.
K content in subsoil and continuous mobilization from non-exchangeable bonds were not considered in the direct balance calculation, leading to discrepancies with measured soil K changes.

specific_results.description: Positive balance only at FYM 1 variant at both sites. Highest negative balance (-2376 kg K/ha) at mineral N fertilization (Humpolec site). Negative balance also for NPK fertilization despite average application of 90 kg K/ha/year. Regular straw incorporation did not influence K balance positively.

temporal_patterns.monitoring_frequency: Soil samples taken at the beginning (1996) and end (2017) of the experiment. Plant harvests occurred annually.

long_term_trends.trend_description: Significant tendency to decrease at the Hněvčeves site in variants without K fertilization.
No significant impact on changes in non-exchangeable K at the Humpolec site, even at variants unfertilized with K in the long term.

long_term_trends.parameter: Potassium content in plough layer (Mehlich 3, Kex, CAT)
long_term_trends.trend_description: Decreased in all unfertilized variants. Highest decrease recorded at mineral N fertilization variant.

explanatory_factors: Higher precipitation and its regular distribution throughout the vegetation period at Humpolec
Soil-forming materials: Cambisol (Humpolec) on paragneiss (releases K), Luvisol (Hněvčeves) on loess (lower potential to release K)
Higher K utilization at soils with higher sorption capacity (Hněvčeves CEC 116 mmol+/kg vs Humpolec CEC 90 mmol+/kg)

cycling_processes.description: Plants are able to absorb some part of non-exchangeable K. In the plant rhizosphere, a K-poor zone forms, leading plants to excrete H+ to release non-exchangeable K. Non-exchangeable K is bound mainly at boundaries of 2:1 clay minerals (mica and vermiculite).

quantification.Hněvčeves_Kne_contribution: Non-exchangeable K was important for replenishing plant-available K in soil at this site (Kne in plough layer ca 3600–3800 kg/ha comparable to K uptake 1124–2111 kg K/ha).
quantification.Humpolec_Kne_contribution: Effect of fertilization on Kne changes may not have been manifested due to very high Kne content (ca 12,500–12,800 kg K/ha) compared to K uptake (1663–2376 kg K/ha).

controlling_factors: Clay mineral type (more important than total clay content)
cycling_processes.measurement_approach: Inferred from changes in Kne content over 21 years and comparison with K uptake.

plant_soil_interactions.interaction_type: Plant K uptake from different soil pools
plant_soil_interactions.description: Plants uptake K from soil solution, exchangeable K, and some part of non-exchangeable K. Root-induced release of interlayer potassium occurs in the rhizosphere.
influencing_factors: Precipitation and its distribution (e.g., higher precipitation at Humpolec led to higher K uptake despite lower bioavailable K)

chemical_processes.characterization: K is strongly sorbed in soils, especially those with higher sorption capacity. Exchangeable K is displaced by excess NH4+.
environmental_controls: Clay mineralogy (2:1 type clays like mica and vermiculite)
chemical_processes.implications: Higher K utilization at soils with higher sorption capacity (Hněvčeves vs Humpolec).

soil_k_effects.K_balance: Highly negative (-1124 to -1663 kg K/ha/21 years)
soil_k_effects.Non_exchangeable_K: Significant decrease at Hněvčeves, no significant change at Humpolec
soil_k_effects.Soil_K_content_change: Decreased in plough layer (e.g., -297 to -273 kg/ha by Mehlich 3)

mechanisms: Continuous crop removal without K replenishment.

soil_k_effects.K_balance: Positive (856 kg K/ha/21 years at Hněvčeves, 48 kg K/ha/21 years at Humpolec)
soil_k_effects.Non_exchangeable_K: No significant change at Humpolec, less decrease at Hněvčeves compared to unfertilized

mechanisms: High K input from manure (2240-2674 kg K/ha/21 years).
K not strongly sorbed in manure (Blake et al. 1999).

experimental_treatments.treatment_description: Half dose farmyard manure + mineral N (FYM 1/2)

soil_k_effects.Exchangeable_K: Increased compared to control, but less than FYM 1
soil_k_effects.Non_exchangeable_K: No significant change at Humpolec, less decrease at Hněvčeves compared to unfertilized

mechanisms: Reduced K input compared to full FYM, leading to negative balance.

soil_k_effects.K_balance: Maximum negative (-1744 to -2376 kg K/ha/21 years)
soil_k_effects.Exchangeable_K: Significantly lowest contents, similar to control
soil_k_effects.Non_exchangeable_K: Significant decrease at Hněvčeves, no significant change at Humpolec
soil_k_effects.Soil_K_content_change: Highest decrease in plough layer (e.g., -221 to -332 kg/ha by Mehlich 3)

mechanisms: No K input, only N, leading to severe K depletion due to crop uptake.

soil_k_effects.K_balance: Negative (-221 to -288 kg K/ha/21 years), despite K input
soil_k_effects.Exchangeable_K: Increased compared to control/N, but still negative balance
soil_k_effects.Non_exchangeable_K: No significant change at Humpolec, less decrease at Hněvčeves compared to unfertilized

mechanisms: K input (1890 kg K/ha/21 years) was insufficient to offset crop removal.

experimental_treatments.treatment_description: Straw of spring barley + mineral N (N + ST)

soil_k_effects.K_balance: Highly negative (-1557 to -1755 kg K/ha/21 years)
soil_k_effects.Exchangeable_K: Increased compared to control/N, but still low
soil_k_effects.Non_exchangeable_K: Significant decrease at Hněvčeves, no significant change at Humpolec

mechanisms: Low K input from straw (282-336 kg K/ha/21 years) insufficient to meet crop demand.

comparative_analysis.comparison_type: K utilization from different fertilizer types
comparative_analysis.notes: Higher K utilization at mineral fertilization may be caused by lower dose of K applied compared to manure treatments. At lower application doses, their utilisation is generally better.

analytical_methods.procedure_description: 3.00 g soil sample extracted with 30 mL solution of 0.02 mol/L CH3COOH, 0.25 mol/L NH4NO3, 0.015 mol/L NH4F, 0.013 mol/L HNO3, 0.001 mol/L EDTA. Shaken for 5 min. K content measured by ICP-OES.

Modified procedure by Haby et al. (1990). 3.00 g soil sample extracted with 30 mL 1 mol/L ammonium acetate solution at pH 7.00. Shaken for 2 h, centrifuged. K concentrations analyzed by ICP-OES. (Displaces rapid exchangeable potassium from exchange sites).

target_parameters: Total K extracted by strong acid
analytical_methods.procedure_description: Helmke and Sparks (2000). 2.5 g finely ground soil sample heated with 25 mL of 1 mol/L HNO3 in an Erlenmeyer flask on a hot plate for 10 min after boiling started. Cooled for 5 min, filtered, diluted to 100 mL with 0.1 mol/L HNO3. K concentration determined by ICP-OES. Kne calculated by subtracting NH4OAc-determined K from boiling HNO3 values.

CSN EN 13651 (2001). 3.00 g soil sample weighed into 50 mL tubes. 30 mL solution of 0.01 mol/L CaCl2 and 0.01 mol/L 0.002 diethylenetriaminepentaacetic acid (DTPA) applied. Shaken for 1 h. Extracts filtered and measured on ICP-OES.
Plant samples (grain, straw, tubers) dried at 40°C, proceeded with dry decomposition (Mader et al. 1998). K content measured.

sampling_design.spatial_sampling: Soil samples from 0–30 cm depth, four replications per plot. Data evaluated based on samples from plots with spring barley.
sampling_design.temporal_sampling: Soil samples taken in autumn 1996 (before experiment establishing) and in 2017 (end of 7th crop rotation, shortly after plant harvest).
sampling_design.sample_processing: Air-dried soil samples (≤ 2 mm) for most extractions. Finely ground soil samples for boiling HNO3 extraction. Plant samples dried at 40°C and dry decomposed.
sampling_design.storage_handling: Not explicitly stated beyond 'air-dried soil samples'.
sampling_design.representativeness: Long-term stationary field experiments designed to represent intensive farming systems in the Czech Republic.

method_comparisons.comparison_results: High correlation: Pearson’s r = 0.989 (Hněvčeves, P < 0.001), 0.958 (Humpolec). Relationships: y = 0.974x + 7.6145, R² = 0.9772 (Hněvčeves); y = 0.9505x + 5.6757, R² = 0.9815 (Humpolec). Suggests Mehlich 3 mainly releases exchangeable K. High agreement attributed to long-term field trials.
method_comparisons.notes: At ordinary agricultural soils, the agreement would probably be lower.

method_comparisons.comparison_results: CAT extraction revealed significantly lower K content compared to Mehlich 3 and NH4OAc (CAT values were only 60–65% compared to the previous methods). The ratio of values (Hněvčeves/Humpolec) for CAT was opposite compared to Mehlich 3 and NH4OAc methods, possibly due to different clay particle character.
method_comparisons.notes: CAT method was stated to be sensitive at variants with added clay sorbents of the smectite type.

method_comparisons.comparison_results: Expressed as % of K content extracted by boiling 1 mol/L HNO3 (100%): Hněvčeves (1069 mg K/ha): M3 18.8%, CAT 10.1%, Kex 19.1%, Kne 80.9%. Humpolec (3167 mg K/ha): M3 4.9%, CAT 3.7%, Kex 4.8%, Kne 95.2%. Mehlich 3 and NH4OAc methods show similar extraction strength.
method_comparisons.notes: Highlights the dominant contribution of non-exchangeable K to the total extractable K by strong acid, especially at Humpolec.

climate_conditions.precipitation: Hněvčeves: 573 mm (mean annual); Humpolec: 665 mm (mean annual)
climate_conditions.seasonality: Regular distribution of precipitation throughout the vegetation period at Humpolec noted as positive influence on K uptake.

soil_properties.classification: Hněvčeves: Haplic Luvisol; Humpolec: Stagnic Cambisol
soil_properties.texture: Hněvčeves: Clay loam; Humpolec: Sandy loam
soil_properties.mineralogy: Hněvčeves: on loess; Humpolec: on loess on paragneiss (parent material of Cambisol, paragneiss, releases K in significant amounts; Luvisol on loess has markedly lower potential to release K). Clay minerals of 2:1 types (mica and vermiculite) are important for non-exchangeable K binding.

landscape_context.topography: Hněvčeves: 265 m a.s.l.; Humpolec: 525 m a.s.l.
landscape_context.land_use_history: Long-term field experiments (21 years) with consistent crop rotation and fertilization treatments.

research_integration.relationship_to_other_measurements: K balance calculations integrate K inputs (fertilizers, straw) and K outputs (crop uptake, determined by yield and plant K content). Soil K measurements (Mehlich 3, NH4OAc, CAT, HNO3) are compared to K balance and changes over time.
research_integration.integration_with_plant_studies: Plant K uptake is a key component of the K balance. K content in different plant parts (grain, straw, tubers) and crop yields are measured and used to calculate K removal from the soil.
research_integration.connection_to_broader_objectives: The research is important from the viewpoint of long-term sustainable soil management in the Czech Republic, especially considering the low annual potassium doses in mineral fertilizers (5–6 kg K/ha agricultural soil) over more than 20 years.
research_integration.comparative_context: Compares results across two sites with different soil and climatic conditions, and across six different long-term fertilization treatments. References other long-term experiments (Blake et al. 1999, Liu et al. 2010, Srinivasarao et al. 2014) for K content and balance.
research_integration.literature_positioning: Builds upon existing knowledge of K extraction methods (Egner-Riehm, Mehlich 3, CAT, NH4OAc, boiling HNO3) and K dynamics in soil, particularly the role of non-exchangeable K.

methodological_constraints: The high agreement between Mehlich 3 and NH4OAc methods is, to a certain extent, given by the fact that the study evaluates corresponding long-term field trials; at ordinary agricultural soils, the agreement would probably be lower.
Not all of the non-exchangeable K may be used by plants, as it is released continuously during many years.
interpretation_caveats: The calculated changes in K content in the plough layer (Table 6) are lower than the negative K balance (Table 3). This is explained by continuous mobilization of potassium from non-exchangeable bonds and by not considering the K content in the subsoil, which is also a significant potassium source for plants.

extraction_assessment.extraction_notes: All explicit soil potassium-related information, including quantitative data, methodological details, and contextual factors, has been extracted. The 'Table Data' section at the end of the prompt was identified as a mis-extraction of figures and was ignored in favor of the textual descriptions and actual tables (1-6) within the paper content.

paper_id: Balance of potassium in two long-term field experiments with different fertilization treatments.pdf
